title: Leon Wagner
text:
Leon Lamar Wagner (May 13, 1934 – January 3, 2004) was an <a href="Americans">American</a> <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> <a href="left%20fielder">left fielder</a> who played <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) for the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Giants">San Francisco Giants</a> (–, ), <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a> (), <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Angels">Los Angeles Angels</a> (–), <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> (–), and <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> (). He batted left-handed and threw right-handed.
Born in <a href="Chattanooga%2C%20Tennessee">Chattanooga, Tennessee</a>, Wagner graduated from <a href="Tuskegee%20University">Tuskegee University</a>. He was affectionately known as "Daddy Wags" during his playing days. This was due to his distinctive left-handed batting style and his notable and unique body gesticulations, primarily below the waist, before going into his devastating stride. His outfield play did not match his stellar hitting. He was at least briefly in the clothing business, advertising his venture as "Get your glad rags from "Daddy Wags". He was also known as "Cheeky" for his high cheekbones (being of half Native American and half African-American descent).
MLB career.
Wagner, over the course of his 12-season MLB career, <a href="Batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">hit</a> .272, with 211 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s, and 669 <a href="Run%20batted%20in">RBI</a>, in 1352 <a href="Games%20played%23Baseball">games</a>.
Wagner broke into the big leagues at age 24 for the San Francisco Giants in their first year in San Francisco on June 22, 1958. A solid line-drive hitter and colorful player, he compiled a .307 batting average with 13 home runs in 74 games as a rookie. Competing for playing time against a congested Giant <a href="outfielder">outfield</a> that included <a href="Willie%20Mays">Willie Mays</a>, <a href="Felipe%20Alou">Felipe Alou</a>, <a href="Orlando%20Cepeda">Orlando Cepeda</a>, and <a href="Bill%20White%20%28first%20baseman%29">Bill White</a> (all of whom were superior fielders), he was traded to the Cardinals after the 1959 season.
Wagner was relegated to a reserve role for St. Louis in 39 games and hit four home runs; one of them was notable as being the first <a href="Home%20run">homer</a> ever hit in <a href="Candlestick%20Park">Candlestick Park</a>, on April 12, 1960, accounting for the lone Cardinal run in a 3–1 loss to his former team.
Upon being traded to the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> (AL) expansion Angels in (their first season), Wagner found himself a regular for the first time. He took advantage of the opportunity, hitting .280, with 28 home runs, and 79 RBI, in 133 games. His most productive season came in 1962, when he blasted 37 homers (third highest in the AL), amassed 107 RBI, 96 <a href="Run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a>, 164 <a href="Hit%20%28baseball%29">hits</a>, and 21 <a href="Double%20%28baseball%29">doubles</a> (all career highs), while batting .268. Wagner played in both <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star Games</a> that season (two All-Star Games were held, each year from 1959 through 1962); in the second contest, he went 3-for-4, including a two-run home run. Wagner was voted the second All-Star game's most valuable player and became the first AL player to receive the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20All-Star%20Game%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">All-Star Game MVP Award</a> that was first introduced that year and for both games. The first true <a href="Slugging%20percentage">slugger</a> in Angel history, he hit 91 home runs with 276 RBI in 442 games for them. But in 1963, after his second All-Star selection, he was sent to the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> in the same trade that brought slugging first baseman <a href="Joe%20Adcock">Joe Adcock</a> and pitcher <a href="Barry%20Latman">Barry Latman</a> to the Angels. (Leon Schwab, a drugstore owner in <a href="Hollywood">Hollywood</a>, upon hearing that Wagner had been dealt to the Indians, remarked that his son-in-law had asked, "Is "that" all they got for Wagner?") 
Wagner had truly come to enjoy playing and living in Los Angeles, and resented the Angels for trading him … some folks close to him say, for the rest of his life.
As a Cleveland left fielder, Wagner hit 97 home runs from to . His best year with the Indians was , when he hit 31 homers, with 100 RBI, and 94 runs. In he hit .294 with 28 homers. Wagner also stole 26 bases in 30 attempts in 1964–65.
Wagner ended his career as a respected <a href="Pinch%20hitter">pinch-hitter</a>, leading the AL in 1968 with 46 appearances in that role, while splitting the season between the Indians and the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a>. Purchased by the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> in December, 1968, he was returned to the White Sox on April 5, 1969, only to be released by them the same day. (Although his 1969 <a href="Topps">"Topps" baseball card</a> depicted Wagner as a member of the Reds, he, in fact, never played a single regular-season game for them.)
Wagner then signed as a <a href="free%20agent">free agent</a> with his first big league team, the Giants, and made his final appearance, as the Giants hosted the expansion <a href="San%20Diego%20Padres">San Diego Padres</a>, October 2, 1969. Although he had begun his MLB career with the Giants in and ended his career with them eleven seasons later, Wagner’s Giants games played total amounted to only 172 of his MLB career 1152-game total.
Acting career.
Following the end of his playing career, Wagner appeared in small acting roles, most prominently in <a href="John%20Cassavetes">John Cassavetes</a>' <a href="1974%20in%20film">1974</a> film "<a href="A%20Woman%20Under%20the%20Influence">A Woman Under the Influence</a>" and as a member of a Depression-era <a href="Barnstorm%20%28sports%29">barnstorming</a> team in "<a href="The%20Bingo%20Long%20Traveling%20All-Stars%20%26amp%3B%20Motor%20Kings">The Bingo Long Traveling All-Stars & Motor Kings</a>" (<a href="1976%20in%20film">1976</a>).
Death.
Wagner struggled with alcohol and drug issues, having had numerous financial difficulties after his baseball career ended. He lived in an abandoned electrical shed next to a dumpster in Los Angeles, which is where his lifeless body was found on January 3, 2004. The coroner ruled that Wagner had died of natural causes.
